value: Aberaeron's harbour and picturesque Georgian houses

Aberaeron is a Welsh-speaking seaside town, with multicoloured houses, a harbour and many small independent shops.
There is no train station. The nearest is in Aberystwyth, from where there are buses. By road, the main A487 runs through the town.
It's about a 20 minute drive to
. To the south there are good beaches at Llangrannog and Cwmtydu.

value: The town and harbour. Aberaeron is well known for its multicoloured houses and buildings. Take a stroll down the High Street and around the harbour. Look out for the local family of Bottle-nosed Dolphins out to sea.
content=Lovely little shop selling locally-produced delicacies. The farmhouse cheeses are a particular favourite.
content=Fishing tackle and other sports gear

The Harbourmaster Hotel ('Gwesty'r Harbwr' in Welsh) has a superb restaurant, specialising in seafood. For a cheaper, yet tasty and substantial meal, try the New Celtic fish-and-chips restaurant (eat in or take away).

The Famous Holgate's
. Also holds a cafe/restaurant serving more substantial meals. Located exactly where the name implies!

value: content= A great cafe/takeaway specialising in baguettes and Segafredo coffee. Great quality food at very reasonable prices with a warm and friendly atmosphere.
price=£80-£120 per night for bed and breakfast
content=A cobalt blue small hotel with views of the sea and harbour.

content=Located in the centre of the famous seaside town of Aberaeron, West Wales, 'Nant Meigan' is a Grade 2 listed Georgian terrace holiday let, in the centre of a historic town.  A five minute walk to the pebble beach, and backing onto the river Aeron, the property enjoys a walled garden that provides privacy and tranquility, centrally located to give you plenty of choices for enjoyable outings in West Wales and your own Welsh Holiday
